node.title: Can Smeared Cracking be Coupled with Production (Single Phase flow, Permeability Changes)
node.bodyText:
I want to know, what features that MOOSE does't support while I am using smeared cracking (continuum damage mode) coupled with flow in porous media to simulate hydraulic fracturing propagation and then productions (flow in to the location of damage factor = 1).
I think I need to change the permeability at the grids with damage factor = 1, after this, I need to run another flow in porous media, or it can they be coupled? In-stitu stress needs to be considered.
Can you also see some convergence issue for coupling these two methods?
@cpgr @rpodgorney
Adding @lynnmunday , he has been doing smeared cracking runs in Falcon

I used PorousFlowFullySaturated with coupling_type = HYDROMECHANICAL which will set up the kernels for coupling porous flow and mechanics i.e. PorousFlowEffectiveStressCoupling and PorousFlowVolumetricStrain and the mechanics kernel.  However, unlike the Physics/SolidMechanics action, this does not create a strain calculator material i.e. ComputeIncrementalSmallStrain, so you need to include that like I have below.
I have this auxvar for the smeared cracking strain that I use in the below to modify the permeability.
[AuxVariables]
  [./crack_max_strain1]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]
[AuxKernels]
  [./crack_strain1]
    type = MaterialRealVectorValueAux
    property = crack_max_strain
    variable = crack_max_strain1
    component = 0
  [../]
[]

This is the auxkernel to modify the permeability.  I also tried to compute the aperture but it was 2 order magnitude too large.  That is why I'm using a made up relationship between permeability and smeared cracking strain instead of a^2/12.  The crack_perm function needs work, maybe it should look like the maybe_better_perm auxkernel but that gives too large of a crack.  A better measure of the element length normal to the crack face would give a better strain measure.
[AuxKernels]
[crack_perm]
  type = ParsedAux
  variable = crack_perm
  coupled_variables = 'permeability crack_max_strain1'
  expression = 'permeability *(1 + ${three_s_over_a0} * max(0, crack_max_strain1))'
  execute_on = NONLINEAR
[]
[maybe_better_perm]
  type = ParsedAux
  variable = crack_perm_not_used
  coupled_variables = 'permeability crack_max_strain1 elem_length_min'
  expression = 'a:=(crack_max_strain1*elem_length_min); permeability + (a)^2/12'
  execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
[]
[aperture]
  type = ParsedAux
  variable = aperture
  coupled_variables = 'crack_max_strain1 elem_length_min'
  expression = '(crack_max_strain1*elem_length_min)'
  execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
[]
[]

This is my porous flow and smeared cracking materials :
[Materials]
  [porosity]
    type = PorousFlowPorosityConst
    porosity = porosity 
  []
  [permeability]
    type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConstFromVar
    perm_xx = crack_perm
    perm_yy = crack_perm
    perm_zz = crack_perm
  []
  [elasticity_fracture]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = ${rock_young}
    poissons_ratio = ${rock_poisson}
  []
  [strain]
    type = ComputeIncrementalSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  []
  [elastic_stress]
    type = ComputeSmearedCrackingStress
    cracking_stress = 1.2e7
    softening_models = abrupt_softening
    max_stress_correction = 0.  #using zero lags damage by a timestep
    shear_retention_factor = 0.1
    cracked_elasticity_type = FULL
    output_properties = true
    perform_finite_strain_rotations=false
  []
  [abrupt_softening]
    type = AbruptSoftening
    residual_stress = 0.05
  []
  [undrained_density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = density
    prop_values = ${rock_gravitational_density}
  []
[]

To make this work, you need to define some kind of weakened field for the smeared cracking model to fracture along or a some distribution of initial damage.  Other wise you will get isotropic damage around the highest pressure point.  You can also use a spatially varying permeability to spread out damage
Let me know if you get something working with the aperture.

I used PorousFlowFullySaturated with coupling_type = HYDROMECHANICAL which will set up the kernels for coupling porous flow and mechanics i.e. PorousFlowEffectiveStressCoupling and PorousFlowVolumetricStrain and the mechanics kernel. However, unlike the Physics/SolidMechanics action, this does not create a strain calculator material i.e. ComputeIncrementalSmallStrain, so you need to include that like I have below.
I have this auxvar for the smeared cracking strain that I use in the below to modify the permeability.
[AuxVariables]
  [./crack_max_strain1]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]
[AuxKernels]
  [./crack_strain1]
    type = MaterialRealVectorValueAux
    property = crack_max_strain
    variable = crack_max_strain1
    component = 0
  [../]
[]

This is the auxkernel to modify the permeability. I also tried to compute the aperture but it was 2 order magnitude too large. That is why I'm using a made up relationship between permeability and smeared cracking strain instead of a^2/12. The crack_perm function needs work, maybe it should look like the maybe_better_perm auxkernel but that gives too large of a crack. A better measure of the element length normal to the crack face would give a better strain measure.
[AuxKernels]
[crack_perm]
  type = ParsedAux
  variable = crack_perm
  coupled_variables = 'permeability crack_max_strain1'
  expression = 'permeability *(1 + ${three_s_over_a0} * max(0, crack_max_strain1))'
  execute_on = NONLINEAR
[]
[maybe_better_perm]
  type = ParsedAux
  variable = crack_perm_not_used
  coupled_variables = 'permeability crack_max_strain1 elem_length_min'
  expression = 'a:=(crack_max_strain1*elem_length_min); permeability + (a)^2/12'
  execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
[]
[aperture]
  type = ParsedAux
  variable = aperture
  coupled_variables = 'crack_max_strain1 elem_length_min'
  expression = '(crack_max_strain1*elem_length_min)'
  execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
[]
[]

This is my porous flow and smeared cracking materials :
[Materials]
  [porosity]
    type = PorousFlowPorosityConst
    porosity = porosity 
  []
  [permeability]
    type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConstFromVar
    perm_xx = crack_perm
    perm_yy = crack_perm
    perm_zz = crack_perm
  []
  [elasticity_fracture]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = ${rock_young}
    poissons_ratio = ${rock_poisson}
  []
  [strain]
    type = ComputeIncrementalSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  []
  [elastic_stress]
    type = ComputeSmearedCrackingStress
    cracking_stress = 1.2e7
    softening_models = abrupt_softening
    max_stress_correction = 0.  #using zero lags damage by a timestep
    shear_retention_factor = 0.1
    cracked_elasticity_type = FULL
    output_properties = true
    perform_finite_strain_rotations=false
  []
  [abrupt_softening]
    type = AbruptSoftening
    residual_stress = 0.05
  []
  [undrained_density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = density
    prop_values = ${rock_gravitational_density}
  []
[]

To make this work, you need to define some kind of weakened field for the smeared cracking model to fracture along or a some distribution of initial damage. Other wise you will get isotropic damage around the highest pressure point. You can also use a spatially varying permeability to spread out damage

Hi, by any chance, is there an example that you can share with me so that I can understand the structure and make changes to make it work?
I'll post it. I just need to clean it up first.

I'll post it. I just need to clean it up first.

node.title: Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic
node.bodyText:
How do I solve the error below in my input script?
No SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic action can be block unrestricted if more than one SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic action is specified.

[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]
  strain = FINITE
  add_variables = true
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [eta0_dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta0
  []
  [eta1_dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta1
  []
[]

Hello
I think you mean to use this syntax
[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]
  strain = FINITE
  add_variables = true
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]


[Kernels]
  [eta0_dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta0
  []
  [eta1_dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta1
  []
[]

node.title: Warning in SolidMechanics
node.bodyText:
Hello
I met a warning,
*** Warning ***
Missing coupled variables {temp} (add them to coupled_variables parameter of TM_fuel0)

This warning occurs in Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic, but my MOOSE version is not the latest so it occurs in Modules/TensorMechanics/Master.
The solution is I need to add temperature = temp. But the convergence is poor when i did it.
Since it's just warning the simulation can continue, should I necessarily add temperature = temp? And what's this setting about, would it make a big difference to the result?

hello
Do you want to model thermal expansion or not? This is what it controls.
If convergence is poor with it, maybe the parameters for the thermal expansion are not set right. For example the reference temperature for the thermal eigenstrain.
Guillaume

1.If i don't set temperature = temp, it still models thermal expansion. So whats the difference?
2.Besides, i set stress_free_temperature = 300, which 300 is the initial condition of temperature.
Is that wrong?

1.If i don't set temperature = temp, it still models thermal expansion. So whats the difference?

not sure but if you are getting a warning without then you should address it
What about the thermal expansion coefficient?

node.title: [Dynamics - Explicit/CentralDifference] - mesh/elements deform with just gravity load when use TET but HEX works fine
node.bodyText:
Hi guys, this is a very simple input file
just a mesh with ramp up ONLY gravity, when I used elem_type = HEX8 or elem_type = HEX20
it worked fine, got results as expected

However, when I set elem_type = TET4 or TET10 the mesh deforms quite drastically!


not sure, why is this the case.
below is my input file, we want to stick with explicit CentralDifference
we dont mind changing other parameters, maybe something inside DynamicSolidMechanics isnt right for TET?
Thank you guys!
Traiwit
[Mesh]
[gen]
  type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
  dim = 3 # Dimension of the mesh
  nx = 10 # Number of elements in the x direction
  ny = 10 # Number of elements in the y direction
  nz = 30 # Number of elements in the z direction
  xmin = 0.0
  xmax = 1000
  ymin = 0.0
  ymax = 1000
  zmin = 0.0
  zmax = 1000
  # allow_renumbering = false # So NodalVariableValue can index by id
  show_info = true
  elem_type = HEX8
  # elem_type = TET4
[]
[]
  
  [Variables]
    [./disp_x]
    [../]
    [./disp_y]
    [../]
    [./disp_z]
    [../]
  []
  
  [AuxVariables]
    [./vel_x]
    [../]
    [./accel_x]
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
    [../]
    [./accel_y]
    [../]
    [./vel_z]
    [../]
    [./accel_z]
    [../]
  []
  
  [AuxKernels]
    [./accel_x]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_x
      displacement = disp_x
      first = false
    [../]
    [./vel_x]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_x
      displacement = disp_x
      first = false
    [../]

    [./accel_y]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_y
      displacement = disp_y
      first = false
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_y
      displacement = disp_y
      first = false
    [../]

    [./accel_z]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_z
      displacement = disp_z
      first = false
    [../]
    [./vel_z]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_z
      displacement = disp_z
      first = false
    [../]
  []

    [Kernels]

    [./DynamicSolidMechanics] # zeta*K*vel + K * disp
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
      stiffness_damping_coefficient = 0.000025
      # mass_damping_coefficient = 0.001
      # eigenstrain_names = ini_stress
      strain = SMALL
      incremental = true
    [../]

    [./inertia_x]
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_x
    [../]
    [./inertia_y]
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_y
    [../]
    [./inertia_z]
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_z
    [../]

    [./gravity]
        type = Gravity
        variable = disp_z
        function = '-9.81*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 30))'
        value = 1
    [../]
  []


  
  [BCs]

    [./no_x_back]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_x
      boundary = 'back'
      value = 0.0
    [../]
    [./no_y_back]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_y
      boundary = 'back'
      value = 0.0
    [../]
    [./no_z_back]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_z
      boundary = 'back'
      value = 0.0
    [../]

   # fixed x left
    [./no_x_left]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_x
      boundary = 'left'
      value = 0.0
    [../]
    [./no_y_left]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_y
      boundary = 'left'
      value = 0.0
    [../]
      

    # fixed x right
     [./no_x_right]
       type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
       variable = disp_x
       boundary = 'right'
       value = 0.0
     [../]
     [./no_y_right]
       type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
       variable = disp_y
       boundary = 'right'
       value = 0.0
     [../]

     # fixed y top
      [./no_x_top]
        type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
        variable = disp_x
        boundary = 'top'
        value = 0.0
      [../]
      [./no_y_top]
        type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
        variable = disp_y
        boundary = 'top'
        value = 0.0
      [../]

      # fixed y bottom
       [./no_x_bottom]
         type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
         variable = disp_x
         boundary = 'bottom'
         value = 0.0
       [../]
       [./no_y_bottom]
         type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
         variable = disp_y
         boundary = 'bottom'
         value = 0.0
       [../]
  []

  
   # * if(t=0, 0, if(t>=(target_time), 1, (t) / (target_time) ))
  [Functions]
    [./ini_xx]
        type = ParsedFunction
        expression = '-2.5*9.81*2700*(1000-z)*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 305))'
      [../]
      [./ini_yy]
        type = ParsedFunction
        expression = '-2.5*9.81*2700*(1000-z)*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 30))'
      [../]
      [./ini_zz]
        type = ParsedFunction
        expression = '-9.81*2700*(1000-z)*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 30))'
      [../]
  []
  
  [Materials]
    [./elasticity_tensor]
      youngs_modulus = 30e9 #Pa
      poissons_ratio = 0.3
      type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    [../]
    [./strain]
    #   type = ComputeFiniteStrain
      type = ComputeIncrementalStrain
      # eigenstrain_names = ini_stress
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
      implicit = false
    [../]
    [./stress]
      type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    #   type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    [../]
    [./density]
      type = GenericConstantMaterial
      prop_names = density
      prop_values = 2700 #kg/m3
    [../]
    [./ini_stress]
      type = ComputeEigenstrainFromInitialStress
      eigenstrain_name = ini_stress
      # initial_stress = 'ini_xx 0 0 0 ini_yy 0 0 0 ini_zz'
      initial_stress = '0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0'
    [../]
  []


  
  [Executioner]
    type = Transient
    start_time = 0
    end_time = 30
    dt = 0.005
    timestep_tolerance = 1e-6
    [./TimeIntegrator]
      type = CentralDifference
      solve_type = lumped
    [../]
  []
  
  [Postprocessors]
    [./accelz_avg]
      type = ElementAverageValue
      variable = accel_z
    [../]
    [./velz_avg]
      type = ElementAverageValue
      variable = vel_z
    [../]
    [./disp_z_avg]
      type = ElementAverageValue
      variable = disp_z
    [../]
  []
  
  [Outputs]
    exodus = true
  []

okay, i think my DT is too big
when i use
    [TimeStepper]
      type = PostprocessorDT
      postprocessor = time_step
    []
    
     [time_step]
      type = CriticalTimeStep
      factor = 1
      density = density
      # density_scaling = density_scaling
      execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
    []

it suggested smaller dt than 0.005 (like 0.3ish in this particular case) BUT for real cases, it will take forever for my simulation to finish
I attempted to use density_scaling (aka mass scaling)
    [density_scaling]
      type = DensityScaling
      density = density
      desired_time_step = 0.005
      output_properties = density_scaling
      # outputs = 'exodus'
      factor = 0.8
    []

but it doesn't seem to work, sure the dt from DensityScaling is not 0.005 BUT it still not stable
can someone please guide me on how to properly use DensityScaling.
thank you!
Traiwit

So it makes sense that you need a small dt for central difference. However, I have never used density scaling before and wasn't aware it existed. Are we sure it was developed for these applications and developed with tets in mind? Was it @recuero who developed it?
Also, I doubt we have a page for tet vs hex for explicit dynamics, unless it was developed recently.

This was not developed with tets in mind. I am not even sure if the critical time step object considers that particular case. I don't even believe there are decent tets for mechanics in the code.
The logic for doing mass scaling is very easy. @Traiwit can probably look into that.
@recuero is correct about critical time step. We did not consider tets when developing that. Just hex elements and beams I think.

You can make sure that _effective_stiffness has the correct value (IIRC it's a material property that needs to be actively populated in each object). I assume the minimum element size must be correct since that comes from libMesh. Then, you can test, without mass scaling, that the critical time step prediction gives you a stable simulation.
If all makes sense, then double check that that the density/mass is getting added properly to increase the stable time step size.
I would also make sure that hmin is appropriate for tets.

Hi @recuero and @cbolisetti
i just did some tests, few things I can confirm:
CriticalTimeStep alone works fine with TET elements, HOWEVER the dt it gives is really small (our mine-scale model would take months to solve).
Hence, I want to use density scaling (mass scaling), I checked, it calculated density_scaling correctly according to _desired_time_step given
void
CriticalTimeStep::execute()
{
  const Real dens = _material_density[0];
  const Real dens_scaling = _density_scaling ? (*_density_scaling)[0] : 0.0;

  // In the above line, density is inferred only at the first quadrature point
  // of each element. Since critical time step is computed across all elements and
  // a minimum is then taken, this is okay.

  _critical_time = std::min(_factor * _current_elem->hmin() * std::sqrt(dens + dens_scaling) /
                                (_effective_stiffness[0]),
                            _critical_time);

  Real computed_value = _factor * _current_elem->hmin() * std::sqrt(dens + dens_scaling) / (_effective_stiffness[0]);
  Real computed_value_nodenscaling = _factor * _current_elem->hmin() * std::sqrt(dens) / (_effective_stiffness[0]);

  // Print the critical time step and dens_scaling for debugging
  std::cout << "Critical Time Step: " << _critical_time << std::endl;
  std::cout << "Density : " << dens << std::endl;
  std::cout << "Density Scaling: " << dens_scaling << std::endl;
  std::cout << "computed_value : " << computed_value << std::endl;
  std::cout << "computed_value_nodenscaling : " << computed_value_nodenscaling << std::endl;
}

for example, this simple case, the desired dt is 0.005
original density is 2700
some node needs density scaling value of 6675 so dt can be 0.005
without density_scaling dt would be 0.00268 (tested with this, it was very stable)
so now the dt of the system after density_scaling becomes 0.005 and the system isnt stable at all (Uz, Az, Velz are exploding)
Critical Time Step: 0.005
Density : 2700
Density Scaling: 0
computed_value : 0.033541
computed_value_nodenscaling : 0.033541
Critical Time Step: 0.005
Density : 2700
Density Scaling: 0
computed_value : 0.00536656
computed_value_nodenscaling : 0.00536656
Critical Time Step: 0.005
Density : 2700
Density Scaling: 0
computed_value : 0.033541
computed_value_nodenscaling : 0.033541
Critical Time Step: 0.005
Density : 2700
Density Scaling: 0
computed_value : 0.00536656
computed_value_nodenscaling : 0.00536656
Critical Time Step: 0.005
Density : 2700
Density Scaling: 6675
computed_value : 0.005
computed_value_nodenscaling : 0.00268328
Critical Time Step: 0.005
Density : 2700
Density Scaling: 6675
computed_value : 0.005
computed_value_nodenscaling : 0.00268328


Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+
| time           | accelz_avg     | disp_z_avg     | time_step      | velz_avg       |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+
:                :                :                :                :                :
|   1.800000e-01 |  -3.739382e+07 |  -3.806278e+05 |   5.000000e-03 |  -3.739382e+07 |
|   1.850000e-01 |   2.819791e+08 |   2.870256e+06 |   5.000000e-03 |   2.819791e+08 |
|   1.900000e-01 |  -2.125949e+09 |  -2.164012e+07 |   5.000000e-03 |  -2.125949e+09 |
|   1.950000e-01 |   1.602551e+10 |   1.631253e+08 |   5.000000e-03 |   1.602551e+10 |
|   2.000000e-01 |  -1.207807e+11 |  -1.229448e+09 |   5.000000e-03 |  -1.207807e+11 |
|   2.050000e-01 |   9.101535e+11 |   9.264660e+09 |   5.000000e-03 |   9.101535e+11 |
|   2.100000e-01 |  -6.857508e+12 |  -6.980452e+10 |   5.000000e-03 |  -6.857508e+12 |
|   2.150000e-01 |   5.166023e+13 |   5.258670e+11 |   5.000000e-03 |   5.166023e+13 |
|   2.200000e-01 |  -3.891243e+14 |  -3.961047e+12 |   5.000000e-03 |  -3.891243e+14 |
|   2.250000e-01 |   2.930661e+15 |   2.983247e+13 |   5.000000e-03 |   2.930661e+15 |
|   2.300000e-01 |  -2.206944e+16 |  -2.246554e+14 |   5.000000e-03 |  -2.206944e+16 |
|   2.350000e-01 |   1.661760e+17 |   1.691593e+15 |   5.000000e-03 |   1.661760e+17 |
|   2.400000e-01 |  -1.251123e+18 |  -1.273588e+16 |   5.000000e-03 |  -1.251123e+18 |
|   2.450000e-01 |   9.418648e+18 |   9.587808e+16 |   5.000000e-03 |   9.418648e+18 |
|   2.500000e-01 |  -7.089849e+19 |  -7.217208e+17 |   5.000000e-03 |  -7.089849e+19 |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+



from here I would thought density_scaling should go into the system too, not just in CriticalTimeStep calculation
I found that InertialForce [Kernels] also take density_scaling (I checked via print, it's taken), but it still doesn't help with stability.
now I wonder if I missed something important? or the way i setup Kernels accidentally ignore density_scaling input?

  [Variables]
    [./disp_x]
    [../]
    [./disp_y]
    [../]
    [./disp_z]
    [../]
  []
  
  [AuxVariables]
    [./vel_x]
    [../]
    [./accel_x]
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
    [../]
    [./accel_y]
    [../]
    [./vel_z]
    [../]
    [./accel_z]
    [../]
  []
  
  [AuxKernels]
    [./accel_x]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_x
      displacement = disp_x
      first = true
    [../]
    [./vel_x]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_x
      displacement = disp_x
      first = true
    [../]

    [./accel_y]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_y
      displacement = disp_y
      first = true
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_y
      displacement = disp_y
      first = true
    [../]

    [./accel_z]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_z
      displacement = disp_z
      first = true
    [../]
    [./vel_z]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_z
      displacement = disp_z
      first = true
    [../]
  []

    [Kernels]

    [./DynamicSolidMechanics] # zeta*K*vel + K * disp
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
      use_displaced_mesh=false
      stiffness_damping_coefficient = 0.000025
      # mass_damping_coefficient = 0.001
      eigenstrain_names = ini_stress
      strain = SMALL
      incremental = true
      newmark_beta = 0
      newmark_gamma = 0.5
      # decomposition_method = HughesWinget
    [../]

    [./inertia_x]
      type = InertialForce
      use_displaced_mesh=false
      variable = disp_x
      density_scaling = density_scaling
    [../]
    [./inertia_y]
      use_displaced_mesh=false
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_y
      density_scaling = density_scaling
    [../]
    [./inertia_z]
      use_displaced_mesh=false
      type = InertialForce
      variable = disp_z
      density_scaling = density_scaling
    [../]

    [./gravity]
        type = Gravity
        use_displaced_mesh=false
        variable = disp_z
        function = '-9.81*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 30))'
        value = 1
        
    [../]
  []

I can confirm that
density_scaling also doesn't work for HEX
below i used density scaling with desired time of 0.007 but criticaltimestep suggested 0.0053 (this is with HEX8), Uz_avg also exploded
# Test for the central difference time integrator in 3D.

[Mesh]
[gen]
  type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
  dim = 3 # Dimension of the mesh
  nx = 4 # Number of elements in the x direction
  ny = 4 # Number of elements in the y direction
  nz = 50 # Number of elements in the z direction
  xmin = 0.0
  xmax = 1000
  ymin = 0.0
  ymax = 1000
  zmin = 0.0
  zmax = 1000
  # allow_renumbering = false # So NodalVariableValue can index by id
  show_info = true
  elem_type = HEX8
  # elem_type = TET10

[]
[]
  
  [Variables]
    [./disp_x]
    [../]
    [./disp_y]
    [../]
    [./disp_z]
    [../]
  []
  
  [AuxVariables]
    [./vel_x]
    [../]
    [./accel_x]
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
    [../]
    [./accel_y]
    [../]
    [./vel_z]
    [../]
    [./accel_z]
    [../]
  []
  
  [AuxKernels]
    [./accel_x]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_x
      displacement = disp_x
      first = true
    [../]
    [./vel_x]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_x
      displacement = disp_x
      first = true
    [../]

    [./accel_y]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_y
      displacement = disp_y
      first = true
    [../]
    [./vel_y]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_y
      displacement = disp_y
      first = true
    [../]

    [./accel_z]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_z
      displacement = disp_z
      first = true
    [../]
    [./vel_z]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_z
      displacement = disp_z
      first = true
    [../]
  []

    [Kernels]
    [./DynamicSolidMechanics] # zeta*K*vel + K * disp
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
      use_displaced_mesh=false
      # stiffness_damping_coefficient = 0.000025
      # mass_damping_coefficient = 0.001
      eigenstrain_names = ini_stress
      strain = SMALL
      incremental = true
      decomposition_method = HughesWinget
    [../]

    [./inertia_x]
      type = InertialForce
      use_displaced_mesh=false
      variable = disp_x
      density_scaling = density_scaling
    [../]
    [./inertia_y]
      type = InertialForce
      use_displaced_mesh=false
      variable = disp_y
      density_scaling = density_scaling
    [../]
    [./inertia_z]
      type = InertialForce
      use_displaced_mesh=false
      variable = disp_z
      density_scaling = density_scaling
    [../]

    [./gravity]
        type = Gravity
        use_displaced_mesh=false
        variable = disp_z
        function = '-9.81*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 30))'
        value = 1
    [../]
  []


  
  [BCs]

    [./no_x_back]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_x
      boundary = 'back'
      value = 0.0
    [../]
    [./no_y_back]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_y
      boundary = 'back'
      value = 0.0
    [../]
    [./no_z_back]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_z
      boundary = 'back'
      value = 0.0
    [../]

   # fixed x left
    [./no_x_left]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_x
      boundary = 'left'
      value = 0.0
    [../]
    [./no_y_left]
      type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
      variable = disp_y
      boundary = 'left'
      value = 0.0
    [../]
      

    # fixed x right
     [./no_x_right]
       type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
       variable = disp_x
       boundary = 'right'
       value = 0.0
     [../]
     [./no_y_right]
       type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
       variable = disp_y
       boundary = 'right'
       value = 0.0
     [../]

     # fixed y top
      [./no_x_top]
        type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
        variable = disp_x
        boundary = 'top'
        value = 0.0
      [../]
      [./no_y_top]
        type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
        variable = disp_y
        boundary = 'top'
        value = 0.0
      [../]

      # fixed y bottom
       [./no_x_bottom]
         type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
         variable = disp_x
         boundary = 'bottom'
         value = 0.0
       [../]
       [./no_y_bottom]
         type = DirichletBC
          preset = false
         variable = disp_y
         boundary = 'bottom'
         value = 0.0
       [../]
  []

  
   # * if(t=0, 0, if(t>=(target_time), 1, (t) / (target_time) ))
  [Functions]
    [./ini_xx]
        type = ParsedFunction
        expression = '-2.5*9.81*2700*(1000-z)*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 305))'
      [../]
      [./ini_yy]
        type = ParsedFunction
        expression = '-2.5*9.81*2700*(1000-z)*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 30))'
      [../]
      [./ini_zz]
        type = ParsedFunction
        expression = '-9.81*2700*(1000-z)*if(t=0, 0, if(t>=30, 1, (t) / 30))'
      [../]
  []
  
  [Materials]
    [./elasticity_tensor]
      youngs_modulus = 20e9 #Pa
      poissons_ratio = 0.25
      type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    [../]
    [./strain]
    #   type = ComputeFiniteStrain
      type = ComputeIncrementalStrain
      eigenstrain_names = ini_stress
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
      # implicit = false
    [../]
    [./stress]
      type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    #   type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    [../]
    [./density]
      type = GenericConstantMaterial
      prop_names = density
      prop_values = 2700 #kg/m3
    [../]
    [./ini_stress]
      type = ComputeEigenstrainFromInitialStress
      eigenstrain_name = ini_stress
      initial_stress = 'ini_xx 0 0 0 ini_yy 0 0 0 ini_zz'
    [../]
    [density_scaling]
      type = DensityScaling
      density = density
      desired_time_step = 0.007  #suggested dt is 0.0053
      output_properties = density_scaling
      outputs = 'exodus'
      factor = 0.8
    []
  []


  
  [Executioner]
    type = Transient
    start_time = 0
    end_time = 30
    num_steps = 100
    # dt = 0.005
    # timestep_tolerance = 1e-6
    [./TimeIntegrator]
      type = CentralDifference
      use_constant_mass = false
      solve_type = lumped
    [../]
    [TimeStepper]
      type = PostprocessorDT
      postprocessor = time_step
    []
  []
  
  [Postprocessors]
    [time_step]
      type = CriticalTimeStep
      factor = 0.8
      density = density
      density_scaling = density_scaling
      execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN TIMESTEP_END'
    []
    [./accelz_avg]
      type = ElementAverageValue
      variable = accel_z
    [../]
    [./velz_avg]
      type = ElementAverageValue
      variable = vel_z
    [../]
    [./disp_z_avg]
      type = ElementAverageValue
      variable = disp_z
    [../]
  []
  
  [Outputs]
    exodus = true
  []

node.title: Why the result of cylinder heat conduction simulated from MOOSE is very different from the theory resolution?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
The theory resolution for heat conduction problem in a cylinder with inner heat source:

Imagine a heat conduction problem in a cylinder with inner heat source:
q = 2240000, T_w = 300, R=0.5, k=200, L = 10. In heat conduction theory, the temperature distribution will be 𝑇 = −(q/4𝑘)𝑟^2 + T_w + (q𝑅^2)/(4𝑘). The maximum temperature is certainly in the middle, when r = 0, T will be 1000.
So I edit 2DCylindricalTube.i:
[Mesh]
 [gmg]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 5
    ny = 10
    xmin = 0.0
    xmax = 0.5
    ymin = 0.0
    ymax = 10.0
  []
  coord_type = RZ
  rz_coord_axis = Y
[]

[Variables]
  [temp]
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 300.0
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [heat_1]
    type = HeatConduction
    variable = temp
  []
  [heat_2]
    type = HeatSource
    variable = temp
    function = 2240000.0
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [daore_steel]
    type = HeatConductionMaterial
    temp = temp
    thermal_conductivity = 200.0
  []
[]

[Problem]
  type = FEProblem
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = PJFNK
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [output_heat]
    type = SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral
    variable = temp
    boundary = right
    diffusivity = thermal_conductivity
  []
  [output_Tmax]
    type = NodalMaxValue
    variable = temp
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [rightbc]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    boundary = right
    value = 300.0
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

However, the result is

Tmax does not equal to 1000.
So I also edit 3DCylindricalTube.i:
[Mesh]
  [accg]
    type = AdvancedConcentricCircleGenerator
    ring_radii = '0.5'
    ring_intervals = '5'
    ring_block_ids = '15 20'
    ring_block_names = 'inner_tri inner'
    external_boundary_id = 100
    external_boundary_name = 'right'
    num_sectors = 40
    preserve_volumes = False
  []
  
  [extrude1]
    type = AdvancedExtruderGenerator
    input = accg
    heights = 10.0
    num_layers = 10
    direction = '0 0 1'
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [temp]
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 300.0
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [heat_1]
    type = HeatConduction
    variable = temp
  []
  [heat_2]
    type = HeatSource
    variable = temp
    function = 2240000.0
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [daore_steel]
    type = HeatConductionMaterial
    temp = temp
    thermal_conductivity = 200.0
  []
[]

[Problem]
  type = FEProblem
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = NEWTON
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [output_heat]
    type = SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral
    variable = temp
    boundary = right
    diffusivity = thermal_conductivity
  []
  [output_Tmax]
    type = NodalMaxValue
    variable = temp
  []
  [volume]
    type = VolumePostprocessor
    block = '15 20'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [rightbc]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    boundary = right
    value = 300.0
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

The result is

Tmax does not equal to 1000.
Why both of these result is quite different from the theory resolution? The error departures from the theory resolution is too high I think. Do I need to change something in [Steady] part? I try set l_tol or nl_rel_tol to fix this, but it seems useless, it only iterates more times and send me the same result......

Hello
We can look at that in further depth once you've investigated this fully. For now
    ring_intervals = '5'
    num_sectors = 40

this is a lot of sectors which do not help to model the radial variation, and not a lot of radial discretization. The sectors help capture the true volume of the cylinder, which is important for the correct definition of the power density variable. How far off is the cylinder volume from the analytical cylinder?
Please up this radial discretization so that the polynomial (quadratic) true shape of the solution is captured better
Guillaume

Thanks! I refined the 3D mesh and 2D mesh. After enhancing the radial discretization, the result calculated is near the theory resolution. I think you are right!
For 3D mesh, I give my result:

And for 2D mesh, I give my result:

node.title: Source term calculation
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
All,
In my model, I solve diffusion and heat equations. For the diffusion equations, I need to calculate the source/sink terms which are dependent on variables and parameters and it needs more than the "functions" with "ParsedFunction" type calculations. Please let me know if I should use the "Material system computing" or something else?
Please help. S. Thomas

Hello
If the reaction / source / sink terms are simple linear functions of a variable then you can use CoupledForce to add that term to an equation
If it s any more complicated then I would recommend using ADMatCoupledForce with an ADParsedMaterial to describe the term
Guillaume

All,
I would like to use the sink value I calculate in "Material System" and input into "BodyForce" in "Kernels System" via "Functions System."  In the attached function object "SinkMat", "_value_mat[_qp]" is the sink value I calculate in "Material System."  I got an error message for "_value_mat(getMaterialProperty("value_mat"))."  Is this approach not work?  Please help.  S. Thoms
SinkMat.pdf
SinkMat.pdf

All,
I would like to make sure that I put the correct files in the previous post.
Please help, S. Thomas
SinkMat_C.pdf
SinkMat_h.pdf

All,
I also tried to modify the BodyForce" object (please see Attached).  It is not still working.
Pease help, S. Thomas
BodyForceMat_C.pdf
BodyForceMat_h.pdf

I calculate in "Material System" and input into "BodyForce" in "Kernels System" via "Functions System."

you cant use Materials in Functors.
You need to find a different kernel. Or create a new one
For example CoupledForce can use a variable, which can bring material properties through the ParsedAux auxkernel

Thank very much for the suggestion. I still have errors as below which I don't understand.
Pease help, S. Thomas
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/768/projects/run/build/unity_src/functions_Unity.C...
In file included from /Users/768/projects/run/build/unity_src/functions_Unity.C:2:
/Users/768/projects/run/src/functions/SinkMat.C:19:54: error: expected expression
  params.addParam<MaterialPropertyName>("value_mat", <a default if it makes sense, if not then none>, "description");
                                                     ^
/Users/768/projects/run/src/functions/SinkMat.C:19:55: error: use of undeclared identifier 'a'
  params.addParam<MaterialPropertyName>("value_mat", <a default if it makes sense, if not then none>, "description");
                                                      ^
/Users/768/projects/run/src/functions/SinkMat.C:19:84: error: expected expression
  params.addParam<MaterialPropertyName>("value_mat", <a default if it makes sense, if not then none>, "description");
                                                                                   ^
/Users/768/projects/run/src/functions/SinkMat.C:25:16: error: use of undeclared identifier 'getMaterialProperty'
    _value_mat(getMaterialProperty<Real>("value_mat"))
               ^
/Users/768/projects/run/src/functions/SinkMat.C:32:21: error: use of undeclared identifier '_qp'
  return _value_mat[_qp];

hello
when we <...> in code it's meant for you to fill in, you can't copy paste it in it wont work without filling it

Sorry ... I will type then.  The errors are:
.../functions_Unity.C:2:: ... /functions/SinkMat.C:19:54: error: expected expression.
params.addParam<MaterialPropertyName>("value_mat",<a default if it makes sense, if not then none>, "description");
... /functions/SinkMat.C:19:55: error: use of undeclared identifier 'a'
params.addParam<MaterialPropertyName>("value_mat", <a default if it makes sense, if not then none>, "description");
... /functions/SinkMat.C:25:16: error: use of undeclared identifier 'getMaterialProperty'
_value_mat(getMaterialProperty('value_mat")

I still receive an error of
... /functions/SinkMat.C:25:16: error: use of undeclared identifier 'getMaterialProperty'
_value_mat(getMaterialProperty('value_mat")

Using the ParsedAux auxkernel as you suggested before may be a good idea.
S. Thomas

node.title: Build CUDA aware MOOSE - Issues to buils PETSc - SUPERLU_DIST
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Issue or question about MOOSE
Hello.
I have been trying to build MOOSE with CUDA aware OpenMPI an PETSc, but my efforts have been unsuccessful until now.
OpenMPI is CUDa aware in my build, but when I try to build PETSc it fails to make SUPERLU_DIST.

Configure_petsc.sh is been called wth the options:
python3 ./configure --with-64-bit-indices 
--with-cxx-dialect=C++17 
--with-debugging=no 
--with-fortran-bindings=0 
--with-mpi=1 
--with-openmp=1 
--with-cuda=1 
--with-shared-libraries=1 
--with-sowing=0 
--download-fblaslapack=1 
--download-hypre=1 
--download-metis=1 
--download-mumps=1 
--download-ptscotch=1 
--download-parmetis=1 
--download-scalapack=1 
--download-slepc=1 
--download-strumpack=1 
--download-superlu_dist=1 
$HDF5_STR 
$MUMPS_ARM_STR 
$MAKE_NP_STR 
"$@"
I atach the PETSc config.log.
configure.log
Thank in advance.
Diagnostics for MOOSE installation issues
[Optional] Output of the diagnostics scripts. To run the script: cd ~/projects/moose/scripts; ./diagnostics.sh

Hello
You could remove superlu-dist by manually editing the update and rebuild petsc script
Guillaume
@DanoLV I added https://gitlab.com/petsc/petsc/-/merge_requests/7572 off petsc/release to get more info on the failure of detecting cuda arch.  You might want to have a try.

Thaks you all for the comments.
All this stuff is pretty new for my, so I do not really get all the details.
What I can tell is that I'm using a GeForce GTX 1080, which has compute capability 6.1. So it meets the requirements.
Finally, I did manage to get a complete build of MOOSE that works!
To make it work, I installed CUDA 12.5, HDF5 1.14.4, UCX 1.16.0,  and  OpenMPI 5.0.3 first. Then, downloaded MOOSE and changed the PETSc vesion. When the script update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh gets PETSc from github, it downloads version 3.20. I replaced it with version 3.21.1 and commented the lines from the script to avoid it beening replaced again. Afted that I did not get another errors in the build proccess.
I set the scrip configure_petsc.sh to run with these options:
python3 ./configure --with-64-bit-indices 
--with-cxx-dialect=C++17 
--with-debugging=no 
--with-fortran-bindings=0 
--with-mpi=1 
--with-openmp=1 
--with-cuda=1 --with-cuda-dialect=cxx17 -CUDAOPTFLAGS="" -Wno-deprecated-gpu-targets --download-kokkos --download-kokkos-kernels
--with-shared-libraries=1 
--with-sowing=0 
--download-fblaslapack=1 
--download-hypre=1 
--download-metis=1 
--download-mumps=1 
--download-ptscotch=1 
--download-parmetis=1 
--download-scalapack=1 
--download-strumpack=1 --download-slate
--download-slepc=1 
--download-superlu_dist=1 
$HDF5_STR 
$MUMPS_ARM_STR 
$MAKE_NP_STR 
"$@"
After that, I continued with the steps explained in https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html#!
The run_tests execution gives several error, but it seems to be due to the lack of definition of -vec_type -mat_type in the tests definitions. I have to do more checks on this matter.

Thank you for posting. I've been working on getting a Cuda variant Conda package set made available to the masses, and your input helps.
With older PETSc versions I was being stopped by several PETSc contribs. But your configure line indicates these contribs are now working properly.
I think that any tests using boomeramg will likely fail since boomeramg always assumes the vec and mat will be on the device but by default we just create those on the host

Hi @DanoLV
could you please share your update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh and configure_petsc.sh? i'm having hard time running update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh as well
also did you install CUDA 12.5, HDF5 1.14.4, UCX 1.16.0, and OpenMPI 5.0.3 to your linux or conda environment?
I'm super new to this compile PETSC and GPU stuff, I kept running into error after error, could you please guide me?
Thank you for you help!
Kind regards,
Traiwit

They gave a pretty detailed configure line. Browsing it, I believe the additional arguments you would pass to scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh if you want to mimic their configuration are:
scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh --with-cxx-dialect=C++17 --with-cuda=1 --with-cuda-dialect=cxx17 -CUDAOPTFLAGS="" -Wno-deprecated-gpu-targets --download-kokkos --download-kokkos-kernels
make sure that you've configured openmpi with --with-cuda

/home/dano/discos/datos/proyects/moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/git.superlu_dist/SRC/pdgstrs_lsum_cuda.cu(1746): error: no instance of overloaded function "atomicAdd" matches the argument list

This issue was fixed by https://gitlab.com/petsc/petsc/-/merge_requests/7288/diffs?commit_id=cdfa477dea3fec089d157123d8a6f983b5ff4346
but yeah - generall - best to use latest version for GPU usage

node.title: How to install peacock
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
Hello, everyone. I was confronted with a problem when I installed Peacock into Ubantu according to this instruction https://mooseframework.inl.gov/python/peacock.html. After I inputted command "conda create -n peacock moose-peacock", a error happened like this:
(base) yue@yue-laptop:~$ conda create -n peacock moose-peacock
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: \ Killed
Is there anyone that could help me with this error ? Thank you very much.
(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
(base) yue@yue-laptop:~$ conda create -n peacock moose-peacock
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: \ Killed

Hello
Killed likely means you ran out of memory, unless you killed the process yourself with ctrl C
Guillaume

Thank you very much. This time, I used a linux-based computer with a memory of 32 Gb according to your suggestion. However, a new problem appear like this:
[cloudam@master ~]$ conda create -n peacock moose-peacock
Channels:

https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
anaconda
intel
defaults
Platform: linux-64
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed

LibMambaUnsatisfiableError: Encountered problems while solving:

nothing provides _sysroot_linux-64_curr_repodata_hack 3 h69a702a_13 needed by moose-mpich-4.0.2-build_15

Could not solve for environment specs
The following packages are incompatible
└─ moose-peacock is not installable because there are no viable options
├─ moose-peacock 2022.10.04 would require
│  └─ ca-certificates 2022.9.24 ha878542_0, which does not exist (perhaps a missing channel);
├─ moose-peacock 2022.12.05 would require
│  └─ ca-certificates 2022.12.7 ha878542_0, which does not exist (perhaps a missing channel);
├─ moose-peacock 2023.04.11 would require
│  └─ moose-mpich 4.0.2 build_16, which requires
│     └─ _sysroot_linux-64_curr_repodata_hack 3 h69a702a_14, which does not exist (perhaps a missing channel);
├─ moose-peacock [2023.08.17|2023.08.31|...|2023.11.10] would require
│  └─ paraview, which does not exist (perhaps a missing channel);
└─ moose-peacock 2023.11.29 would require
└─ moose-mpich 4.0.2 build_15, which requires
└─ _sysroot_linux-64_curr_repodata_hack 3 h69a702a_13, which does not exist (perhaps a missing channel).
Could you please help with this problem?
@milljm may know what problem we are having with package dependencies here

Our packages require the conda-forge channel to be made available. And to be strictly used with other packages coming from conda-forge (no mix-and-matching).
This installation looks to be of a miniconda variant (denoting the Anaconda channel there). You can try the following, but it might be necessary to install Miniforge which makes direct use of the 'conda-forge' channel.
conda config --add channels conda-forge
conda config --set channel_priority strict
conda create -n peacock moose-peacock

Also, miniconda is going to be nefariously slow at solving dependencies. This right here:
Solving environment: 

Prepare for this to take some times 40 minutes. It is not broken!
This is why we primarily moved to Miniforge instead (their solver is parallel/threaded, solving dependency chains in a fraction of the time).

node.title: Material for learning implementing in-situ stress and absorbing boundary
node.bodyText:
Are there materials (couldn't find in the documents) about how MOOSE implements the in-situ stress and absorbing boundary (Lysmer et al. I guess?) Like how the in-situ stress affects the initial condition and the solving process, etc
Thanks!

Hello
Which source file in particular? So I can find who implemented it

Hello
Which source file in particular? So I can find who implemented it

I am not into the source file yet, I assume there are these features in MOOSE.
@dschwen

Hello
Which source file in particular? So I can find who implemented it

Anyone would give me some lectures about the in-situ stress in MOOSE?
Is this in a porous-flow geomechanics context or a solid mechanics context?

Is this in a porous-flow geomechanics context or a solid mechanics context?

ah, I would say more of porous-flow geomechancis.
@1runer @cpgr do you know which doc page would fit best?

node.title: Attempting to set parameter  <Use a descriptive title here>
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi,
I have a moose-based app in which I have added a function in a material property as followimg:
in header file:
const Function * Tn;
in source file:
 params.addParam<FunctionName>("mass_function", "The mass flow rate as a ");

followed by a simple calcualtion in the code.
in input file:
Tn = 'function name'
it compiles successfully but when i am running, i shows following error and stops the run.
*** ERROR ***
Attempting to set parameter "Tn_o" with type (FunctionName)
but the parameter already exists as type (double)

Thanks in advance for any help
I have got the same error.

Hello
Do you happen to have
 params.addParam<Real>("mass_function", "The mass flow rate as a ");

in the validParams as well as the FunctionName version?
And if not, what does your class derive from? and does any of the parent have this parameter?
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud,
No i do not have Real version, only have FunctionName version.
it is derived from "CZMComputeLocalTractionTotalBaseRSF3D" and the parant does not have the parameter.

Hi @GiudGiud
I have edited the header and source like the following:
in header file:
public:
  const FunctionName functionName() const;    //returns The function name

protected:
  const Function & _Tn_o;                                   //Function to evaluate 


in  source file:
 params.addParam<FunctionName>("mass_function", "The mass flow rate as a ");
.
.
.
classname::classname(const InputParameters & parameters)
  : CZMComputeLocalTractionTotalBaseRSF3D(parameters),
   _Tn_o(getFunction("Tn_o")),
.
.
.
const FunctionName
classname::functionName() const
{
  return _Tn_o.name();
}

But, i got the same error again.
Thanks for your help

this should be
   _Tn_o(getFunction("mass_function")),

since it uses the name of the parameter

Thanks @GiudGiud
I have followed this ticket #25688 and the issue is resolved.
in next step, I want to check the magnitude of the function after run in paraview and i call it in input file: output_properties = 'Tn_o',
but "Tn_o" does not show up in paraview. It is not added for automatic output at all.
Setting Up
Setting Mesh
Reading Mesh..                                                                       [ 16.43 s] [  388 MB]
Finished Setting Mesh                                                                  [ 18.57 s] [  390 MB]
The following total 1 aux variable:
traction_normal
is added for automatic output by MaterialOutputAction.
Initializing

Hello
There is no Automated function output
Either use a GenericFunctionMaterial to output the function as a material property using the material property output
Or use a FunctionAux to output it as an auxiliary variable

Thnaks @GiudGiud
I already tried in those way and data shows up as an auxvariable.
But waht i mean is that "Tn_o" used like stress in material block, so since i can output stress in exodus file i can output "Tn_o" as well, right?
Actually "Tn_o" is used for initialization of the model, so i want to check if initilazation is done properly? because this app is part of a serial coupling and i need to prove that the results of the app A is transferred to app B properly.

so since i can output stress in exodus file i can output "Tn_o" as well, right?

If Tn_0 is a function then no you can't.

so i want to check if initilazation is done properly

You can use an auxvariable and execute the FunctionAux on INITIAL
